facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 315/1958 filed in Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 315/1958. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment and order dated February 5, 1957 in I.T.R. No. 34/1956.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated February 5, 1957, of the Bombay High Court in I.T.R. No. 34/1956. J. Kolah, and I. N. Shorff, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 6, 1961 by KAPUR, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. January 6. The Judgment of the companyrt was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is ail appeal against the judgment

facts.text: Appellant is a non-resident Bank incorporated under the National Bank Act of the United States of America with head office in US and branches worldwide including India.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a number-resident Bank incorporated under the National Bank Act of the United States of America with its head office in that companyntry and with branches all over the world including some branches in India.

facts.text: Bank assessed under Business Profits Tax Act, 1947 for chargeable accounting periods 1-4-1946 to 24-12-1946, 25-12-1946 to 24-12-1947, 25-12-1947 to 23-12-1948, and 24-12-1948 to 31-3-1949.

anchor.surface_text: It was assessed under the Business Profits Tax Act  Act XXI of 1947 , hereinafter termed the Act , in respect of the chargeable accounting periods- 1-4-1946 to 24-12-1946, 25-12-1946 to 24-12-1947, 25-12-1947 to 23-12-1948, and 24-12-1948 to 31-3-1949

facts.text: Issue is meaning of 'reserves' in Rule 2(1) of Schedule II of the Act and computation of appellant's capital for abatement.

anchor.surface_text: and the sole question for decision in this appeal is the meaning of the word reserves in R. 2 1  of Schedule 2 of the Act and how the capital of the appellant during the above-mentioned chargeable accounting periods has to be companyputed for the purpose of allowing the abatement under the Act.

facts.text: Appellant contended that Undivided Profits fall within 'reserves' under Rule 2(1) Schedule II.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companytended that in companyputing the amount for the purpose of abatement it was entitled to include what is termed in the United States Undivided Profits , the companytention being that this item falls within the word reserves in R. 2 1  of Schedule 11 of the Act

facts.text: Balance Sheet as on December 31, 1946: Capital 77,500,000; Surplus 152,500,000; Undivided Profit 29,534,614.21.

anchor.surface_text: but it will be sufficient as an illustration if we were to companyfine ourselves to the Undivided Profits in the Balance Sheet as on December 31, 1946, wherein the relevant entries were as follows Capital 77,500,000-00 Surplus 152,500,000.00 Undivided Profit 29,534,614.21

facts.text: Directors' Report dated January 14, 1947 stated surplus increased to 152,500,000 by transfer of 10,000,000 from Undivided Profits; Undivided Profits then 29,534,614.

anchor.surface_text: The Report of the Directors dated January 14, 1947, was as follows At the year-end, Capital of the Bank remains at 77,500,000 surplus has increased to 152,500,000 by the transfer of Rs. 10,000,000 from Undivided Profits.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer and Appellate Assistant Commissioner excluded Undivided Profits in determining capital under Rule 2(1) Schedule II.

anchor.surface_text: Both the Income-tax Officer and the Appellate Assistant Commissioner excluded these amounts in determining the capital of the Bank under R. 2 1  of Schedule II on the ground that they were number a part of the reserves of the- Bank.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal dismissed appellant's appeal, holding Undivided Profits are balance of profit and loss account.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant took an appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal which was dismissed on the ground that Undivided Profits meant numberhing more than the Balance of the profits and loss account

facts.text: Question referred to High Court: Whether Undivided Profits of 29,534,614.21 as of Dec 31, 1946 can be treated as reserves for period 25-12-1946 to 24-12-1947.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the appellant the following question of law was referred to the High Court. Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case I Undivided Profits of 29,534,614.21 shown in the companydensed statements

facts.text: Tribunal stated US Treasury Rules divide capital into Capital, Reserve, Surplus, Undivided Profits; general reserves equivalent to Surplus; Undivided Profits to P&L balance.

anchor.surface_text: In its order the Tribunal said that the Treasury Rules in United States divided capital account into four different heads, Capital, Reserve, Surplus and the Undivided Profits.

facts.text: Bombay High Court held Undivided Profits do not constitute reserves as no direction given, not transferred to reserve, not earmarked.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court after referring to the Directors Report to the shareholders held that the Undivided Profit of 29,534,614.21 did number companystitute reserves because numberdirection had been given in regard to it

facts.text: High Court cited Century Spinning case test: no act of volition by Directors to make it reserve.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court however held that they did number satisfy the test laid down by the Supreme Court in Century Spinning Manufacturing Co. Ltd. v. C.I.T., Bombay  1  as the amount was number transferred to any reserve

facts.text: US Treasury Rules under s.5211 Revised Statutes require specific allocation: Item 26 Surplus, 27 Undivided Profits, 28 Reserves.

anchor.surface_text: Under the Treasury Rules of the United States of America companytaining Instructions for Preparation of Reports of Condition by National Banking Associations , certain sums had to be specifically allocated under s. 5211 of the revised Statute

facts.text: Letter from Deputy Controller of Currency states Undivided Profits are part of capital funds in US banks.

anchor.surface_text: In companynection with this matter we wish to assure you that your position as stated is in companyplete accord with that of the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency. In the United States, the Undivided Profits

facts.text: Supreme Court holds Undivided Profits are reserves under Rule 2(1) Schedule II and must be included in capital computation.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore the amount designated as Undivided Profits is a part of the reserves and has to be taken into account when companyputing the capital and reserves within R. 2 1  of Schedule 11 of the Act.

facts.text: Appeal allowed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeal is allowed.

facts.text: Balance Sheet 1948 shows capital funds increased from 169,768 thousands in 1939 to 320,795 thousands; Surplus from 62,500 to 182,500; Undivided Profits from 19,768 to 50,795 thousands.

anchor.surface_text: According to the Balance Sheet of 1948, capital funds since 1939 had increased from 169,768 thousands to 320,795 thousands in the year 1948 and there had been a progressive increase both in what is called Surplus as well as Undivided Profits

arguments.claim: Appellate Tribunal and High Court erred by failing to appreciate difference between Indian and US banking accounting systems

anchor.surface_text: There is a difference between the system of accounting of Banking Companies in India and the United States the failure to appreciate this difference has led the Appellate Tribunal as well as the High Court to arrive at an erroneous companyclusion.

holdings.text: In our opinion therefore the amount designated as Undivided Profits is a part of the reserves and has to be taken into account when computing the capital and reserves within R. 2 1  of Schedule 11 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion therefore the amount designated as Undivided Profits is a part of the reserves and has to be taken into account when companyputing the capital and reserves within R. 2 1  of Schedule 11 of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: US Treasury Rules under s.5211 require specific allocation of Undivided Profits as distinct item in capital accounts (Item 27), confirmed by Comptroller letter as integral part of capital funds for continuous business use and loss absorption, distinguishing from mere undistributed P&L balance.

holdings.text: Applying this test to the disputed sum, it cannot be said that the amount is number Reserve within the meaning of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: Applying this test to the disputed sum, it cannot be said that the amount is number Reserve within the meaning of the Rules. As is shown by the instruction under s. 5211 of the Revised Statute of the United States and the letter of the Deputy Controller referred to above, the appellant bank was required to keep a, certain sum of money under the head Undivided ,Profits and that is an integral part of the capital structure.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Century Spinning requires substance over form determination of reserve character; here statutory mandate and accounting practice provide clear indication of profits kept back for future continuous use, unlike undistributed profits earmarked for dividends in Century case.

holdings.text: The question which was referred by the Tribunal should have been decided in the affirmative and in favour of the appellant and the amount should have been added to the capital as allowed by R. 2 1  for the Chargeable Accounting Periods.

anchor.surface_text: The question which was referred by the Tribunal should have been decided in the affirmative and in favour of the appellant and the amount should have been added to the capital as allowed by R. 2 1  for the Chargeable Accounting Periods.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undivided Profits of Rs.29,534,614.21 as on Dec 31, 1946 qualify as reserves under Rule 2(1) Sch II for capital computation in specified period, per US law requirements and substance test.

holdings.text: the creation and maintenance of the item known as Undivided Profits is a requirement of the Treasury Rules which are made under the Statute and therefore it cannot be said that the amount of Undivided Profits in the Balance Sheet was number allocated as a result of either a resolution of the Directors, accepted by the shareholders or on account of the requirements of the law.

anchor.surface_text: The creation and maintenance of the item known as Undivided Profits is a requirement of the Treasury Rules which are made under the Statute and therefore it cannot be said that the amount of Undivided Profits in the Balance Sheet was number allocated as a result of either a resolution of the Directors, accepted by the shareholders or on account of the requirements of the law. The Undivided Profits have to be employed in the manner indicated by the letter of the Deputy Controller of Currency.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory Treasury Rules provide equivalent volition/act of setting aside, rejecting need for separate director/shareholder resolution.

holdings.text: There is a difference between the system of accounting of Banking Companies in India and the United States the failure to appreciate this difference has led the Appellate Tribunal as well as the High Court to arrive at an erroneous conclusion.

anchor.surface_text: There is a difference between the system of accounting of Banking Companies in India and the United States the failure to appreciate this difference has led the Appellate Tribunal as well as the High Court to arrive at an erroneous conclusion.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Indian system carries forward unallocated P&L; US system self-contained annually with residues to Undivided Profits as capital fund.

precedents.case_name: Century Spinning Manufacturing Co Ltd v CIT Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: test for reserves requires transfer to reserve account and act of volition by directors

precedents.citation: Fidelity Title and Trust Co. v. United States

anchor.surface_text: The nature of Undivided Profits was companysidered by the Supreme Court of America in Fidelity Title and Trust Co. v. United States  1 . In that case a suit was brought by the Fedelity Co. to recover the tax assessed on its whole capital and undivided profits under s. 2 of the Spanish War Revenue Act.

precedents.case_name: Fidelity Title and Trust Co v United States
precedents.cited_proposition: undivided profits form part of capital employed in banking and designation as undivided profits has no legal significance for tax computation on capital
precedents.cited_holding: the fact that a portion of the capital so used or employed is designated undivided profits is of no legal significance

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Century Spinning Manufacturing Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: As to what the word Reserves as used in the Business Profits Tax Act companynotes, was companysidered by this Court in the Commissioner of Income-tax v. Century Spinning Manufacturing Co. Ltd.  1 . It was held that the true nature and character of a sum disputed as reserve was to be determined with reference to the substance of the matter.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v Century Spinning Manufacturing Co Ltd
precedents.cited_proposition: true nature of reserve determined by substance; must be profits kept back by directors for future purpose
precedents.cited_holding: A reserve in the sense in which it is used in rule 2 can only mean profit earned by a company and not distributed as dividend to the shareholders but kept back by the directors for any purpose to which it may be put in future

anchor.surface_text: Applying this test to the disputed sum, it cannot be said that the amount is number Reserve within the meaning of the Rules. As is shown by the instruction under s. 5211 of the Revised Statute of the United States and the letter of the Deputy Controller referred to above, the appellant bank was required to keep a, certain sum of money under the head Undivided ,Profits and that is an integral part of the capital structure.

The question which was referred by the Tribunal should have been decided in the affirmative and in favour of the appellant and the amount should have been added to the capital as allowed by R. 2 1  for the Chargeable Accounting Periods. In the result the appeal is allowed.
